column3: Could you include an explanation as to why the html is being excluded in your commit message, for the historical record?
I tend to NACK here since `%1word` seems less understandable for translators then `<b>word`.

Yes, that makes sense, since I'm not removing any tag like `<span style='{complicated_style}'>` on this.\nI suppose this PR only makes sense if the priority is to ban HTML tags from tr() calls. And, unfortunately, as far as I know Qt has no better-looking built-in way to do this without splitting phrases for every style tag; which would probably make translations even trickier for many languages.

NACK. I agree with the premise that using HTML in translation messages should be avoided if possible, However I disagree with this specific solution: %1...%2 is not clearer than using HTML, and more error-prone.
@marcoagner are you aware of any project where your approach is used? or if there is a discussion of the pros and cons elsewhere?\n\nI agree with @jonasschnelli though so NACK..
Given your points, I don't think I have a strong case for now with this specific approach.\nThank you all for the time and thoughtful inputs.
@marcoagner You could probably whitelist `<b>` if you wanted to reject html tags?
nit: Why the added block `{ â€¦ }`?

Recommenting so the edits do not clutter it (specially because I switched "declaration" by "initialization", oops). As you can see [here](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/switch): `"Because transfer of control is not permitted to enter the scope of a variable, if a declaration statement is encountered inside the statement, it has to be scoped in its own compound statement:"`. So the alter
nit: %1, %2 would be more intuitive given there is no %1
nit: Could do this inline, ala line 120

I agree but the line was very convoluted like `tr("Enter the new passphrase.") +
+ tr("Please, use......").arg("", "");` in case of avoiding leave the unnecessary `
`'s placeholder (%1) for translators. Tried this as a middle ground.
Meh... thinking it through, there's not enough reason to force this extra block pattern. Much better just breaking the line and using `+` operator, I think. Thx!
